Do you believe everything is an illusion, or is it real to you? The word ‘illusion’ might be deceptive here. Perhaps if we say that things aren’t entirely the way we infer them to be, it might sound more palatable. In Buddhist-speak they would say that we erroneously infer things to have “inherent existence,” and that it’s also wrong to say that things don’t exist at all. Rather they have what the Buddhists call “conventional existence,” meaning that things only exist in relation to all other things. To put it another way, the existence of all things depends on the existence of all other things. This is the philosophy of Dependent Origination formulated by the Indian Buddhist philosopher Nagarjuna, originally found in the sermons of the Gautama Buddha as a claim that things only stand because they support each other like sheaves of wheat that stand only because they lean against each other. So, without the other sheaves to hold it up, any particular sheaf would not stand. The pertinence of this notion can be seen when the self is considered as a ‘thing.’ So even the self has only a conventional existence and not any inherent existence. Hence the Buddhist notion of no self (no inherently existing self). The notion of self dissolves into the melee of interdependent things and its significance diminshes. And since the notion of an inherently existing self is the root of all desire (the feeling of unsatisfactoriness encapsulated in the thought that “things would be better for me if…”), that feeling of unsatisfactoriness falls away.

The Sanskrit word Maya has been wrongly translated as illusion in the English language and this has caused widespread misunderstanding about this concept. “Ma” means that which is not and “ya” means that which is. Seeing that which is as that which is not is called as Maya or cognitive error. The classical example is that of seeing a snake in a rope in semi darkness. When the light is turned on, the rope is seen as rope and the snake is seen as non-existent. Rope is the reality and the snake superimposed on it in semi darkness is a cognitive error. So there is something out there for sure (cosmos) and in our perception it looks a certain way and we believe that this perception is the absolute reality. That is Maya. Let us take a simple hypothetical example. A man sees a woman as being very beautiful. If he had microscopic vision then he would see millions of microorganisms crawling all over her face and she wouldn’t look so beautiful anymore. If he had near perfect vision then he would see a cloud of sub-atomic particles in the place of the woman surrounded by a vaster cloud of sub-atomic particles making her practically indistinguishable or invisible. Where is the beautiful woman?! Which of these 3 views is the absolute view? None of them! Perception of “what is” is not its absolute nature but it is merely our limited and imperfect view. So when we see a beautiful cosmos we should see clearly that it is merely our limited view or Maya and we have no clue at all as to the absolute reality of “what is” really out there. According to Advaita Vedanta, there is truly no time, space or cosmos in the absolute sense but all there is, is Brahman in a state of deep peace. This Brahman is the material cause as well as the efficient cause of this cosmos. This cosmos emerges out of Brahman much like a cobweb emerges out of a spider. Both the subject and the object arise simultaneously in what we understand as wakefulness and sink in what we understand as deep sleep. So the simple answer to your question is “I live my life in duality and in duality my pain and suffering are very real and not an illusion. However in my sober moments I have recognized the profound Truth that I am part and parcel of Brahman”.

This generates a lot of interesting thoughts. Consider this: When you look at a photograph, are you looking at the objects in the photograph? No, you’re not looking at the objects because they’re not there. They could be miles away, or they could even not exist anymore. This is pretty easy to understand. This is also easy to understand with astronomical objects. Light requires time to travel. A light year is a measure of distance. When we look at an object that’s 1 light year away, we’re seeing how it looked 1 year ago. How does it look right NOW? We don’t know. To know how it looks right NOW, we have to wait until next year. We never see distant stars and galaxies as they are. We only see how they looked in the past. Even though the increment of time may be extraordinarily small, this is true of EVERY object. Everything in our rooms, or even things we hold in our hands, must be seen by us as they existed in the past. Because the light we’re looking at is carrying an image of how things were in the past. We never see the present world. We only see the world as it existed in the past. So if we are always looking at how things were in the past, and we never see the present, is everything we see an illusion?

1st: There is a wonderful book by computational neuroscientist Donald Hoffman called The Case Against Reality: Why Evolution Hid the Truth from Our Eyes.....that will give you a great depth of insight into what is going on inside your brain. To answer your question, I would like to more away from the word illusion and go with simulation (a neurological simulation created by the brain). We know from physics that every object in the world is 99.9999999 % empty space. Because our brain can NOT see and process the data coming from high-speed electrons…so what we see is a "high speed motion picture show". We also know that there is a "blind spot" in the back of the eye that we are typically never aware of. Our eyes and really only focus on a very small part of reality at one time. For example, if you hold out your and look at your thumb… this is the only area that is truly highly focused. Because your eyes move through a process called saccade, your brain takes in information from your eyes while it's moving and helps to give you a whole clear picture (simulates) of what you see in front of you. Best wishes

This question has been asked before here, and seems to be much on the popular mind ever since the success of the movie trilogy The Matrix. It is a deep philosophical question as well, so I will put in my two cents. Believing that it’s all an illusion is a road to psychosis. Of what value is anything if nothing is real? Is the Sun unreal? Certainly not, for he will give me a terrible sunburn if I stay out too long unprotected. If I don’t eat, I get hungry, and if food is completely denied, I’d die. Is life or death unreal? Hindu philosophy generated the idea of Maya. This is the idea that the world seems like a dream, but that’s only because we can’t see it as it really is. Once the blinkers of culture fall from our eyes, we can see reality as it really is.
